questions.solution:
Glycogen Storage Disorder

Incorrect Option Explanation:

  • Muscle phosphorylase: This enzyme deficiency is associated with Glycogen Storage Disease type V(McArdle's disease), which leads to muscle cramping and exercise intolerance, but not with Pompe's disease.
  • Glycogen phosphorylase: This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of glycogen in the liverand is deficient in Glycogen Storage Disease type VI (Hers disease), leading to hypoglycemia, not Pompe's disease.
  • Glucose-6-Phosphatase: Deficiency of this enzyme causes Glycogen Storage Disease type I(Von Gierke disease), characterized by severe hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly, not Pompe's disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pompe's disease is caused by a deficiency in acid maltase (acid alpha-glucosidase), leading to glycogen accumulation in tissues.
  • It is a type of glycogen storage disorder and primarily affects the muscles and heart.
  • The other enzymes listed are associated with different types of glycogen storage disorders(e.g., McArdle's disease, Hers disease, Von Gierke disease).

Pneumonic for Glycogen Storage Disorder

questions.text: Least chances of perinatal transmission seen with?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis A is primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route, and perinatal transmission is rare.

Other options:

(A): Perinatal HSV

  • HSV - 1 seen in 20%
  • HSV -2 seen in 80%

Transmission

  • In utero => 5.5%
  • peripartum -> 80% -> leads to prematurity PROM
  • Post birth > 14.5%

(B): Peripartum and postnatally acquired CMV infection may occur (I) from intrapartum exposure to the virus within the maternal genital tract, (ii) from postnatal exposure to infected breast milk (iii) from exposure to infected blood or blood products, or (iv) nosocomially through urine or saliva.

(D): In maternal Rubella infection cases During the last 10 weeks of gestation, the rate of fetal infection again rises 60%chances for weeks 31 to 36 week and 100% for week 36 and beyond.

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops fetalis can occur due to all except?
questions.solution:
Hydrops fetalis: Swelling/Edema in fetus

Def: Fluid accumulation in 2 or more fetal body compartments

(e-g. peritoneal cavity, pleural, pericardial,subcutaneous space etc.)

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has complaints of chronic cough, foul-smelling bulky and sticky stools, poor weight gain. On kissing the child, salty taste is felt by the parents. History of sibling death who had similar complaints.CFTR gene mutation was detected. Which ion abnormality should be checked for confirmation of the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is a case of Cystic Fibrosis.

confirmation of the diagnosis is done by Sweat chloride test.Test is positive if sweat chloride levels are 60 meq/L or more.

Incorrect Option Explanation:

  • Potassium: Potassium abnormalities are not typically associated with CF for diagnostic purposes.
  • Sodium: Although sodium is involved in CF and is part of the salt sensation felt on the skin, it is chloride that is measured in the sweat chloride test for diagnosis.
  • Bicarbonate: Bicarbonate levels are not used for the diagnosis of CF, although acid-base disturbances can occur as a secondary complication in CF patients.

Key takeaways: Cystic Fibrosis

questions.text: A child with fever presents with the following appearance, as shown. What complication can happen?
questions.solution:
Fever with slapped cheek appearance in given image suggestive of Erythema infectiosum(5th disease).which is caused by Parvovirus B19.

Rare complications in children:Transient Aplastic crisis & Pure red cell aplasia

These complications chances increase if the child has underlying haematological disorders.

Incorrect Option Explanation:

  • Molluscum Contagiosum: This is a viral infection caused by a poxvirus, characterized by raised, waxy, dome-shaped papules with a central umbilication. It does not cause a slapped cheek appearance and is unrelated to Parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Thymoma: A thymoma is a tumor of the thymus gland and is not related to the symptoms of slapped cheek or Parvovirus B19 infection. It is more commonly seen in adults and associated with autoimmune disorders like myasthenia gravis.
  • Lymphoma: Lymphoma typically presents with symptoms like painless lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and fever, but it is not associated with the slapped cheek appearance or complications from Parvovirus B19.

Key Takeaways:

  • Erythema infectiosum (5th disease) is caused by Parvovirus B19 and typically presents with a slapped cheek appearance.
  • Pure Red Cell Aplasia (PRCA) is a rare complication of Parvovirus B19 infection, particularly in children with underlying hematological disorders.

Transient Aplastic Crisis is another potential complication of Parvovirus B19 in susceptible individuals.

questions.text: A 10-week-old child has come for vaccination. In the previous visit at 6 weeks, post-vaccination, the child had developed fever of 40 C and was inconsolable crying for 1 hour. What should be done?
questions.solution:
DPT vaccine

Contraindication

I) Progressive neurological disease

ii)Encephalopathy within 7 days

iii)Anaphylaxis

If these contraindications are present,then omit the pertussis component.Go for only DT vaccine.

Precautions taken while 2nd dose:

If previous dose of DPT was a/w any of the following

  • Fever >40.5°C within 48 hr
  • Hypotonic, hyporesponsive episodes within 48hrs or
  • Persistent inconsolable crying lasting more than 3 hours
  • Seizures within 72 hr of DPT administration

Next step: given DPT but monitor

If any episode recurs in 2nd dose of DPT, then in 3rd dose omit DPT & go for DT

Incorrect Option Explanation:

  • Give DT: This option would be correct only if the child had developed serious adverse effects from the DPT vaccine (e.g., seizures, encephalopathy). Since the previous reaction does not meet the criteria for such severe adverse effects, the child can still receive the full DPT vaccine with proper monitoring.
  • Avoid DPT in any form: This is not correct because the child's previous reaction does not meet the contraindication criteria for excluding the DPT vaccine altogether. The reaction should be monitored, and if symptoms recur severely in the future doses, then the pertussis component would be excluded, and only DTwould be given.
  • Defer vaccination for 1 month: Deferment is not necessary unless the child develops severe reactions during the second dose. If mild symptoms recur, the vaccine can be administered with monitoring.

Key Takeaways:

  • Precautions for DPT vaccine include fever >40.5°C, inconsolable crying, hyporesponsive episodes, and seizures after the previous dose.
  • If the symptoms are mild and do not meet the criteria for severe adverse reactions, the second dose of DPT can be administered with monitoring.
  • If severe reactions occur during the second dose, the pertussis component should be omitted in subsequent doses (only DT vaccine will be given).

questions.text:
NADAS minor criteria for congenital heart disease include (s)?
A. Abnormal S2
B. Systolic Murmur grade 2/6
C. Diastolic Murmur
D. Low BP
questions.solution:
NADAS Criteria


If 1 major or 2 minor criteria are met,there is possibility of Congenital Heart disease.

questions.text: A child presented with fever for 5 days, rash, conjunctivitis and tongue as shown. What shall be the optimum management?
questions.solution:
Strawberry tongue given in image & clinical history of fever,rash & conjunctivitis s/o Kawasaki disease.

Drug of choice for Kawasaki disease is IVIG.

Incorrect Options:

  • Aspirin: Aspirin is used as part of the treatment for Kawasaki disease, but it is not the initial drug of choice. Aspirin is given after IVIG to prevent clot formation and reduce inflammation.
  • Prednisolone: Steroids like prednisolone are generally not the first-line treatment for Kawasaki disease, although they may be considered in cases that do not respond to IVIG or in certain refractory cases.
  • Aspirin(listed again): While aspirin is used in conjunction with IVIG, it is not the optimal initial treatment. The first-line therapy remains IVIG to prevent coronary complications.

Key takeaways: Kawasaki disease

choices.text: Intrapartum suctioning of mouth and oropharynx
Tracheal suction in all vigorous MS babies
Positive-Pressure Ventilation in all non-vigorous MS babies
Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous MS babies

questions.text: True regarding management and resuscitation in a baby born through meconium-stained liquor (MSL)?
questions.solution:
Incorrect Options:

  • Intrapartum suctioning of mouth and oropharynx: This is no longer recommended as routine practice. Studies have shown that routine suctioning of the mouth and oropharynx in the delivery room does not reduce the incidence of meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) and can actually lead to delays in effective resuscitation. Instead, suctioning should be done only if the baby is non-vigorous.
  • Tracheal suction in all vigorous MS babies: Vigorous babies(those who cry and have good muscle tone) do not require tracheal suction. Routine tracheal suction is not recommended in vigorous infants, as they are able to clear their airways on their own.
  • Gentle suction of mouth and nose in vigorous MS babies: While gentle suction of the mouth and nose may be performed to clear secretions, this is not always necessary for a vigorous baby. Vigorous babies typically do not require suctioning unless there is obvious obstruction.

Key Takeaway:

For a non-vigorous baby born through meconium-stained liquor, the correct management is Positive-Pressure Ventilation (PPV), not routine suctioning. The priority is to provide adequate respiratory support, and PPV should be initiated immediately if the baby is non-vigorous.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presented to emergency with multiple episodes of vomiting, diarrhea and altered sensorium. Possibilities can include?
questions.solution:
Severe dehydration- Can be

Vomiting and diarrhea can lead to significant fluid loss, causing dehydration, which may result in altered sensorium

Cerebral sinus thrombosis- Can be

Although less common, cerebral sinus thrombosis can occur in the context of severe infections, dehydration, or coagulopathy, leading to altered sensorium.

Hyponatremia- Can be

Vomiting, diarrhea, and dehydration can result in electrolyte imbalances, including hyponatremia, which can cause altered sensorium.

Incorrect option:

Haemolytic uremic Syndrome

Triad


Key Takeaway:

In this 2-month-old infant with vomiting, diarrhea, and altered sensorium, the most likely causes are:

  • Severe dehydration(due to fluid loss),
  • Cerebral sinus thrombosis(in cases of severe infection or dehydration),
  • Hyponatremia(resulting from fluid and electrolyte imbalances).

Hemolytic uremic syndrome is less likely in this scenario.

questions.text: Match the following?
Expected profile in iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
RBC Indices In Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA)

  • MCV, MCH,MCHC: Low
  • Serum Iron: Low
  • Serum Ferritin: Low
  • % Transferrin Saturation: Low
  • TIBC: High
  • Soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR): High
  • Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP): High

Incorrect Option:

  • Low TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity)
    • False: In iron deficiency anemia, TIBC is actually high. TIBC measures the blood's ability to bind iron, and in the case of iron deficiency, the body produces more transferrin (the protein that binds iron), leading to an increased TIBC.

Key Takeaway:

  • Low Serum Iron: Because of insufficient iron.
  • Low Serum Ferritin: Due to depletion of iron stores.
  • Low Transferrin Saturation: Less iron available to bind to transferrin.
  • High TIBC: The body compensates by increasing transferrin production.

Other markers like Soluble transferrin receptor (sTfR) and Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP) are high in IDA, indicating increased iron demand and impaired hemoglobin production.
